papers.title: Neurologic Complications in Critically III Patients
papers.abstract: Critically ill patients are at risk for neurologic complications [1,2]. Many of these complications are part of diagnostic and therapeutic procedures; others are simply manifestations of a more fulminant disease process. Neurologic complications may put an end to the expectation of full recovery, and outcome is often poor. Neurologic complications in critically ill patients were found in 12% of 175 consecutively studied patients in a medical intensive care unit, but they are likely to be even more prevalent in trauma and transplant units. Patients in whom neurologic complications develop during critical illness have twice the length of stay and are twice as likely to die [1]. Neurologic assessment in the intensive care unit is limited because many patients are fatigued, sleep-deprived, confused, uncooperative, or heavily sedated and are often treated with neuromuscular blocking drugs. There are large gaps in our knowledge of neurologic complications in critically ill patients. Neurologic complications often revolve around three main disturbances: muscle weakness, impaired consciousness, and seizures. This review describes common clinical neurologic complications of a potentially life-threatening illness. Coma or Failure to Awaken A puzzling clinical situation is the failure of patients to awaken after the critical illness has subsided. Familiar to intensive care specialists is the patient receiving mechanical ventilation for acute respiratory failure who does not fully recover to a normal level of consciousness after withdrawal of analgesics, sedatives, and neuromuscular blocking drugs. Neurologic signs typically associated with metabolic encephalopathy, such as multifocal myoclonus, asterixis, and tremor, are absent. The differential diagnosis in these patients is shown in Table 1. Despite the use of new short-acting pharmacologic drugs, a common cause of altered consciousness in critically ill patients is related to the previous administration of sedative drugs that have accumulated over days because of diminished clearance or pharmacologic interaction. In many other patients, an anoxic-ischemic insult from brief but significant hypoxemia or hypotension may produce a diffuse encephalopathy that lingers for weeks.Table 1: Major Causes of Coma in Intensive Care UnitsIn medical intensive care units, failure to awaken often occurs in association with sepsis [3,4]. The central nervous system manifestations in sepsis have not been studied in great detail. Patients with acute confusional episodes or any other persistent cognitive abnormality have been said to have "septic encephalopathy." Whether a distinct metabolic encephalopathy of sepsis exists after exclusion of confounding factors remains unknown. In progressive multiple organ dysfunction from sepsis, severe hypoglycemia, marked hypotension necessitating increasing doses of inotropic medication, and significant hypercapnia may all contribute to impairment of consciousness. Suggested mechanisms for encephalopathy associated with sepsis are decreased cerebral blood flow with similar changes in cerebral extraction ratios, disordered amino acid transport similar to hepatic encephalopathy, microabscesses, and possibly, sustained hypotension, suggesting that septic encephalopathy may be more hypoxemic-ischemic in nature [2]. Whether cytokines, such as interleukin-1 or tumor necrosis factor, directly influence arousal remains unresolved. Other mimicking clinical conditions, such as multiple small intracranial hematomas, should be excluded and may be found as part of disseminated intravascular coagulation [5]. Outcome of patients with septic encephalopathy who remain in coma is poor [4,6]. A possibly underrecognized cause of coma after any type of critical illness is cholesterol embolization. Recent arteriographic procedures may be implicated [7,8]. In a retrospective review of pathologic material from patients who died six months after vascular catheterization, the incidence of cholesterol embolization was 25%, with embolization to the central nervous system in 5% of the patients [8]. The clinical recognition of neurologic manifestations of cholesterol embolization may be difficult, and the signs of diffuse encephalopathy, retinal hemorrhages, and transient hemiparesis are not specific. The positive predictive value of systemic manifestations, such as livedo reticularis, purple toes, renal failure, and muscle weakness, may be higher [8]. Both muscle and renal biopsy specimens may show stacked, needle-shaped crystals. It has been suggested that muscle biopsy has a high sensitivity for demonstrating cholesterol embolization [8]. By comparison, a frequent cause of coma in a surgical intensive care unit is acute renal failure producing acute uremic encephalopathy. Acute uremia occurs in approximately 20% of surgical critically ill patients; conversely, acute dialysis in the hospital is associated with perioperative acute renal failure [9,10]. Valvular heart surgery, coronary artery bypass grafting, and aortic aneurysm surgery typically are associated with postoperative acute renal failure, but the incidence is also high in liver transplantation [11,12] and in major surgical repairs complicated by sepsis or involving significant abdominal gastrointestinal exploration and repair. The development of acute uremia in surgical patients dramatically increases the risk of mortality, which approaches 100% if mechanical ventilation is necessary [10]. The most common causes of acute renal failure in surgically ill patients are renal hypoperfusion and nephrotoxic insults. Not unexpectedly, left ventricular dysfunction, diabetes, and use of nephrotoxic antibiotics are major risk factors in patients with preexisting renal dysfunction. Coma from uremic encephalopathy usually develops gradually from drowsiness, asterixis, and myoclonus to an unresponsive state with virtually no motor response to pain. Frontal release signs may be seen, such as marked snout response or brief jerks of retroflexion of the neck after glabellar tapping and grasp reflexes. Typically, the cranial nerves remain intact, as in many metabolic encephalopathies. Uremic encephalopathy usually is the clear overriding cause of coma when blood urea nitrogen and creatinine have doubled in value, but hypoxemia from significant acute respiratory distress syndrome or increased bilirubin from liver failure may contribute. The effect of dialysis is critical in prognostication. Failure to awaken may indicate that hypoxemic, anoxic, or hypotensive events have occurred. The clinical signs of uremic encephalopathy may completely resolve after dialysis, but in many patients in the surgical intensive care unit, a baseline drowsiness persists after dialysis. After dialysis, a dysequilibrium syndrome may occur, but it is rare. The typical presentation includes combative behavior, severe throbbing headache when lying flat, and myoclonic jerks and cramps. The circumstances almost always include rapid dialysis, extreme baseline predialysis blood urea nitrogen, and first dialysis. More dramatic presentations may include cortical blindness and coma preceded by seizures. Computed tomography scanning may demonstrate significant swelling. Many patients die hours after onset [13,14]. In surgical intensive care units, failure to awaken can be associated with ischemic strokes in multiple arterial territories. This devastating complication frequently occurs after major cardiovascular repairs [15]. Patients in coma from ischemic strokes immediately after surgery often have had a significant perioperative event. Typically, the level of consciousness fails to improve after washout of high doses of narcotic analgesics and anesthetics. In these patients, a brief but significant hypotensive episode may have been noted during surgery, but the anatomical territories of ischemic stroke, often multiple, in these patients do not fit a typical watershed territory Figure 1. Other established sources of postoperative ischemic stroke are retained left ventricular thrombus, severe atherosclerosis of the ascending aorta with marked circumferential involvement of most of this segment and protruding atheroma [16], and postoperative atrial fibrillation [17].Figure 1: Computed tomography scan in a patient with multiple strokes after coronary artery bypass grafting. Note hypodensities in both anterior and middle cerebral artery territories.In many patients, microemboli may cause prolonged neuropsychologic abnormalities. Intellectual deterioration may vary greatly and become evident after the patients return home [18]. With extensive neuropsychologic testing, there may be a prevalence of 30%, which is much higher than that in ischemic strokes in large cerebrovascular territories. In fact, magnetic resonance imaging scans did not find any detectable change after coronary artery bypass grafts [19]. Resuscitation for cardiac or respiratory arrest during any type of critical illness may result in postanoxic-ischemic encephalopathy [20]. Comatose patients after cardiac resuscitation may show clinical signs portending a dismal outlook. Coma alone has no predictive value in the first three days [20]. Certainly, if fixed pupils and myoclonus status epilepticus (brief, persistent, and generalized jerks in limbs and face) are associated with a sustained upward gaze, the probability of a persistent vegetative state and death is high in comatose survivors after cardiac arrest [21,22]. In 40% of comatose patients with myoclonus status epilepticus, computed tomographic scan abnormalities of multiple cerebral infarcts or cerebral edema are demonstrated. It is highly probable that status myoclonus is an agonal phenomenon and should be considered a clinical marker for devastating damage to the brain. Patients in coma after cardiac or respiratory resuscitation can be further investigated by somatosensory evoked potentials. The absence of a bilateral cortical somatosensory response (N20 and P27) with a preserved cervical somatosensory response strongly predicts a vegetative state [23]. Further management decisions should be influenced by these findings. Another population of critically ill patients with a propensity for central nervous system involvement are those who have undergone transplantation, notably liver and heart recipients. After liver transplantation, prompt awakening often signifies adequate graft function. When perioperative sedation has been excluded, failure of patients to awaken after liver transplantation may have several causes. Patients with fulminant hepatic failure are prone to the development of increased intracranial pressure from brain edema [24] and during the anhepatic phase may even have a brief surge in intracranial pressure. In an extremely unfortunate situation, brain death is diagnosed postoperatively [24]. Typically, recovery from cerebral edema takes days before level of consciousness improves. In approximately 10% of patients after liver transplantation, neurotoxicity to cyclosporine develops as early as three days after intravenous administration [25,26]. An acute confusional state with paranoid behavior, tremors, and speech abnormalities may be seen. Some patients become mute, but coma with abnormal motor responses is rare, occurring only if cyclosporine neurotoxicity is not recognized. Magnetic resonance imaging changes in the white matter have been reported with severe manifestations of cyclosporine toxicity [25]. Seizures may occur in the first postoperative days, and, if nonconvulsive status epilepticus follows, it may be a potential cause of failure to awaken. This phenomenon can be recognized in many patients by waxing and waning alertness, stereotypical behavior, and occasional twitching in the face and limbs. Central pontine myelinolysis is a less common cause for failure to awaken in recipients of liver transplants, but it may be underreported [27]. In our series of patients undergoing liver transplantation, we found an incidence of 1% and all presented with stupor. Rapid shifts in plasma osmolality and plasma sodium have been implicated [28,29], but the relationship was not evident in our survey of patients with central pontine myelinolysis [30]. Central pontine myelinolysis can be confirmed by magnetic resonance imaging, which shows a typical bat- or trident-shaped abnormality on axial T2-weighted images. (The trident shape is explained by relative preservation of the corticospinal tracts Figure 2.) Central pontine myelinolysis, although dramatic in its clinical and neuroimaging presentation, has a reasonable potential for recovery [31,32].Figure 2: Axial T2-weighted magnetic resonance image of the pons showing typical trident-shaped high-intensity signal after liver transplantation.Intracranial hematomas are uncommon (less than 1%) but have been found more often in patients with associated thrombocytopenia, bacteremia, or fungemia [33]. In some patients, a mycotic aneurysm can be implicated. Generally, infectious causes of coma after liver transplantation are uncommon. Patients with a transplanted heart generally do well in the perioperative phase. Neurotoxicity from immunosuppression (cyclosporine, OKT3) is uncommon in the intensive care unit [34-36]. Possible reasons are meticulous monitoring of OKT3 dosage by determination of the degree of decrease in CD3 cells in OKT3 and use of cyclosporine at a later stage rather than induction therapy in many immunosuppressive protocols. Patients with cardiac transplants, however, are at particular risk for ischemic stroke [36]. A history of stroke and preoperative carotid stenosis of more than 50% significantly increase the risk of ischemic stroke. After heart or heart-lung transplantation, however, ischemic stroke is most frequently associated with retained thrombi within the graft anastomosis. In summary, multiple causes of coma can be considered in critically ill patients. The setting (medical or surgical intensive care unit) may be important in the differential diagnosis. Unexplained coma should be evaluated by cerebrospinal fluid examination and repeat computed tomography scanning, but the decision to perform additional diagnostic tests in patients who are critically ill and become comatose depends on the underlying condition. In many patients, the cause of coma is obvious after careful review of the medical record. Particular attention should be paid to acute changes in laboratory values (e.g., major shifts in plasma sodium or osmolality), hypoxemic periods or cardiac arrhythmias documented during recent invasive procedures, and any recent change in medication or dosage. Computed tomography scanning should be repeated when initial findings are normal and the neurologic examination is not localizing. Cerebral infarcts may become more evident two to three days after sudden neurologic deterioration. The major causes of coma in medical and surgical intensive care units are summarized in Table 1. Generalized Muscle Weakness Fatigue can be expected in critically ill patients after they have survived their illness. An underlying neurologic abnormality should be considered when the patient is mobilized in a chair but appears considerably weak, when the patient cannot support weight, or when weaning failure cannot be readily explained by previous lung disease or new lung injury. At least three major categories have been recognized: axonal polyneuropathy (critical illness polyneuropathy), typically associated with sepsis; acute steroid myopathy, potentially associated with use of neuromuscular junction blockers; and an as yet undefined prolonged muscle weakness after neuromuscular junction blockers, which may represent a toxic myopathy. (The results of electromyographic and nerve conduction studies are often normal.) The definition of all these syndromes continues to be confusing. Many other possibilities should be considered, and in some patients a previously undiagnosed neurologic disorder may have been present that initially appeared with respiratory failure. The differential diagnoses to be considered in patients in medical and surgical intensive care units are listed in Table 2.Table 2: Causes of Generalized WeaknessaProspective studies of causes of weakness in the intensive care unit are few. Polyneuropathy is most commonly a cause of generalized weakness in the intensive care unit ("critical illness polyneuropathy") [37]. The prevalence in intensive care units is not exactly known, but it may occur in 5%-20% of all patients with sepsis and in 50% of patients remaining in the unit more than two weeks [38-40]. Polyneuropathy of critical illness is often seen in association with sepsis. Factors associated with this type of polyneuropathy include age, extended stay in the intensive care unit, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperglycemia. The clinical features of critical illness polyneuropathy are normal cranial nerve findings, although grimacing may be weak [37,38]. Limb weakness is usually severe and more prominent in the distal distribution. Areflexia is invariably present. Prominent muscle wasting may be observed. Pinprick is usually diminished in a stocking-glove pattern. The disorder resolves in a stereotypical manner: improvement in the upper and proximal portions of the lower limbs is followed by successful weaning and later recovery of the distal muscles of the lower limbs. Outcome is generally good if the patient survives the critical illness [37]. As expected with axonal regeneration, three to four months is needed for improvement. A recent study found a severe residual functional handicap in 20% of seven-year survivors with polyneuropathy [39]. Some patients have persistent weakness of the foot flexors from entrapment neuropathy of the peroneal nerve [37]. Compression neuropathy of the peroneal nerve may occur when paralyzed limbs are everted. Trochanter rolls can prevent this unnecessary complication. Electrophysiologic studies in critical illness polyneuropathy may show typical features of axonal damage, with low amplitudes of compound muscle and sensory nerve action potentials, widespread fibrillation potentials, and positive sharp waves, but nerve conduction velocities are perserved [41]. Phrenic nerve conduction is often absent [37,38]. Autopsy or sural nerve biopsy specimens show severe axonal degeneration of peripheral nerves, mostly in the distal segments. Another important cause of generalized muscle weakness is the use of neuromuscular blocking drugs, particularly pancuronium and vecuronium. Most patients recover within days after administration is discontinued, but some remain weak for weeks. The mechanism of weakness is unresolved. Careful, repeated studies of the neuromuscular junction have not been done, and findings may be normal despite marked limb weakness. A recent prospective study found that metabolites of vecuronium may accumulate in patients with renal failure, metabolic acidosis, and hypermagnesemia [42]. Electrophysiologic data for these patients with prolonged weakness were not available. Complete recovery can be expected [42]. The prevalence of prolonged weakness is low; a recent report noted the occurrence in only 1 of 58 prospectively studied patients. It is unclear whether monitoring with a peripheral nerve stimulator can prevent this complication [43]. A well-recognized but uncommon complication of intravenously administered neuromuscular blocking drugs is acute necrotic myopathy, possibly when the drug is given in combination with large doses of corticosteroids (usually up to 1 g/d) [44,45]. The typical patient in whom the complication occurs has status asthmaticus. Significant loss of myosin has been reported [45]. The outcome appears to be excellent, but data are limited. Recently, a myopathy was described in lung transplant patients. Muscle biopsy revealed loss of myosin. All patients received large doses of corticosteroids but no neuromuscular blocking agents, and sepsis did not develop. Normal creatine kinase levels virtually excluded rhabdomyolysis as a possibility. The underlying cause of this selective loss of myosin is unclear, nor is it clear whether this represents a new syndrome or a variant of acute steroid myopathy [46]. We found that severe necrotic myopathy was more common than polyneuropathy in liver transplant patients but were unable to further delineate the abnormality [47]. Rhabdomyolysis may be a source of weakness in critically ill patients. The most common causes are trauma, ischemia of large muscle compartments from arterial occlusion, and sepsis. Myoglobinuria can be found when rhabdomyolysis is massive. Many patients have considerable weakness and pain. Biceps, quadriceps, and gastrocnemius muscles are tender on palpation and may appear swollen Figure 3.Figure 3: Loss of muscle fibers from necrotic myopathy attributed to weakness caused by rhabdomyolysis.Seizures One may suspect that the circumstances surrounding critical illness make patients considerably more vulnerable to seizures, but generalized tonic-clonic seizures are uncommon in the intensive care unit. Myoclonic jerks may be more common because of their association with many of the drugs, such as ketamine and lidocaine, administered in the medical intensive care unit. Acute metabolic alterations, unpredictable pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics, and multiple drug regimens are precipitating factors. Two studies assessing seizures in the intensive care unit have been published [1,48]. In a two-year prospective study of neurologic complications in 1758 patients, 34 had simple partial seizures, 6 had complex partial seizures, and 20 had seizures that were generalized at onset. Status epilepticus eventually developed in six patients [1]. Most of these patients had a stroke or an infectious disease at the time of seizure. In a recent study from the Mayo Clinic covering nine years, 213 of 27,723 patients (0.8%) admitted to intensive care units had at least one episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizure during their stay in a unit [48]. Of the 213 patients, 103 had a history of seizures, 20 had abused alcohol or drugs, 8 were recovering from organ transplantation, and 27 had surgical trauma or head injury. In the remaining 55 patients, seizures were new in onset. Drug-associated seizures in the intensive care unit are often the result of toxicity [2]. Some antibiotics particularly lower the threshold for seizures, but renal failure or a recent sudden increase in antibiotic dosage is a more common precipitating event. For example, imipenem, but particularly increased levels of cilastatin, rather than the active antibiotic, is a well-known cause of seizures. Drugs associated with seizures in intensive care units are summarized in Table 3.Table 3: Drugs Associated with Seizures in the Intensive Care UnitSeizures associated with drug withdrawal may occur in one third of the patients. In a recent study that specifically addressed new-onset seizures, 18 of 55 patients had seizures associated with drug withdrawal (mostly narcotic analgesics) [48]. Drug toxicity was comparatively uncommon, observed in eight patients (from documented antibiotic toxicity in five and from antiarrhythmic drugs in three). In many narcotics were administered for pain management, and in all patients, moderate doses were repeated intramuscularly for at least one week. Seizures occurred two to four days after sudden withdrawal of narcotics. In patients who have alcohol-related seizures, most of which occur in those with a history of heavy drinking, diagnosis is difficult [49]. Very frequently, a single seizure, almost always self-limiting, develops in these patients, but delirium tremens may follow [49]. An underlying structural lesion needs to be excluded by cranial computed tomographic scan [50]. Benzodiazepines are frequently used to maintain sedation in mechanically ventilated patients. Nonconvulsive status epilepticus may occur after discontinuation of long-term administration of benzodiazepines [51]. Metabolic disorders increase the risk of seizures, but risk is related to the severity of the derangement [52-55]. The risk of seizures developing due to electrolyte abnormalities is low. Most seizures in the intensive care unit occur in patients with postoperative hyponatremia, and the cause is often iatrogenic. Most patients with severe hyponatremia already have an impaired level of consciousness, which is soon followed by generalized tonic-clonic seizures. A very unusual syndrome associated with postoperative hyponatremia in young, healthy women has been described [52]. Arieff [52] and others are credited for their description of very severe hyponatremia in healthy women after elective surgery, but this complication was not found in a recent survey at the Mayo Clinic [55]. Many of these women had excessive administration of free water, resulting in sodium levels of less than 110 mEq/L. Vomiting, most likely associated with narcotics or postoperative syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone, may also have contributed. All patients had grand mal seizures followed within one hour by respiratory arrest. Many remained in a vegetative state, and several patients became brain dead. More hospital surveys are necessary to delineate the prevalence of this catastrophic syndrome. Postoperative severe hyponatremia occurs in men undergoing transurethral resection of the prostate, but the outcome is good despite seizures [56]. In this category of patients, serum osmolarity is high from bladder absorption of hypertonic glycine, which is frequently used as an irrigant. Rapid excretion of glycine by the kidney restores plasma osmolarity. This result suggests that the changes in osmolarity are much more important than a change in plasma sodium and that differences should not be attributed to sex. Hypoglycemia may cause tonic-clonic seizures, but in one of the largest series of patients with symptomatic hypoglycemia, many were known to have epilepsy or were alcoholics [54]. Focal seizures may occur and do not necessarily implicate a preexisting structural lesion. Seizures are more prevalent in critically ill patients with hyperglycemia [53]. Nonketotic hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia may eventually result in refractory status epilepticus, usually with poor outcome. Tonic-clonic seizures may occur when the ionized serum calcium concentration is less than 3 mEq/L. Hypocalcemia in a critically ill patient is usually associated with radical neck dissection surgery but may also result from parathyroid suppression by sepsis, pancreatitis, aminoglycosides, or changes in serum magnesium [57]. Much more commonly, hypocalcemic patients have muscle cramps and irregular twitching, which should not be interpreted as focal seizures. Seizures in patients with transplanted organs often indicate that the immunosuppressive drug has reached toxic levels [58]. In patients with transplanted livers, the incidence of seizures is increased by cyclosporine, OKT3, or FK 506 toxicity Figure 4, ischemic anoxic encephalopathy, subdural hematoma, or fungal abscess [59,60].Figure 4: Upper left panel, Magnetic resonance imaging findings in a patient with seizures and FK 506 toxicity. Note marked hyperintensity signal in the globus pallidus on T1-weighted images, typically seen in patients with advanced liver disease. Upper right panel, Marked hyperintensity signal in white matter and cortex in occipital lobe appears on T2-weighted images in a patient with seizures and an impaired level of consciousness. Lower panels, There was complete resolution of both abnormalities in one month.Conclusion The management plan is often reassessed when additional neurologic injury develops in patients in intensive care units. In some patients with a severe underlying illness, an acute neurologic event is a final complication; in others, it is a temporary setback. The outcome from neurologic complications can be quite favorable, but signs of poor prognosis should be identified early and taken into account when management decisions are made. The clinical spectrum of the neurologic aspects of critical illness is beginning to emerge and become defined.

The development of acute uremia in surgical patients dramatically increases the risk of mortality, which approaches 100% if mechanical ventilation is necessary [10]. The most common causes of acute renal failure in surgically ill patients are renal hypoperfusion and nephrotoxic insults. Not unexpectedly, left ventricular dysfunction, diabetes, and use of nephrotoxic antibiotics are major risk factors in patients with preexisting renal dysfunction. Coma from uremic encephalopathy usually develops gradually from drowsiness, asterixis, and myoclonus to an unresponsive state with virtually no motor response to pain. Frontal release signs may be seen, such as marked snout response or brief jerks of retroflexion of the neck after glabellar tapping and grasp reflexes. Typically, the cranial nerves remain intact, as in many metabolic encephalopathies. Uremic encephalopathy usually is the clear overriding cause of coma when blood urea nitrogen and creatinine have doubled in value, but hypoxemia from significant acute respiratory distress syndrome or increased bilirubin from liver failure may contribute. The effect of dialysis is critical in prognostication. Failure to awaken may indicate that hypoxemic, anoxic, or hypotensive events have occurred. The clinical signs of uremic encephalopathy may completely resolve after dialysis, but in many patients in the surgical intensive care unit, a baseline drowsiness persists after dialysis. After dialysis, a dysequilibrium syndrome may occur, but it is rare. The typical presentation includes combative behavior, severe throbbing headache when lying flat, and myoclonic jerks and cramps. The circumstances almost always include rapid dialysis, extreme baseline predialysis blood urea nitrogen, and first dialysis. More dramatic presentations may include cortical blindness and coma preceded by seizures. Computed tomography scanning may demonstrate significant swelling. Many patients die hours after onset [13,14]. In surgical intensive care units, failure to awaken can be associated with ischemic strokes in multiple arterial territories. This devastating complication frequently occurs after major cardiovascular repairs [15]. Patients in coma from ischemic strokes immediately after surgery often have had a significant perioperative event. Typically, the level of consciousness fails to improve after washout of high doses of narcotic analgesics and anesthetics. In these patients, a brief but significant hypotensive episode may have been noted during surgery, but the anatomical territories of ischemic stroke, often multiple, in these patients do not fit a typical watershed territory Figure 1. Other established sources of postoperative ischemic stroke are retained left ventricular thrombus, severe atherosclerosis of the ascending aorta with marked circumferential involvement of most of this segment and protruding atheroma [16], and postoperative atrial fibrillation [17].Figure 1: Computed tomography scan in a patient with multiple strokes after coronary artery bypass grafting. Note hypodensities in both anterior and middle cerebral artery territories.In many patients, microemboli may cause prolonged neuropsychologic abnormalities. Intellectual deterioration may vary greatly and become evident after the patients return home [18]. With extensive neuropsychologic testing, there may be a prevalence of 30%, which is much higher than that in ischemic strokes in large cerebrovascular territories. In fact, magnetic resonance imaging scans did not find any detectable change after coronary artery bypass grafts [19]. Resuscitation for cardiac or respiratory arrest during any type of critical illness may result in postanoxic-ischemic encephalopathy [20]. Comatose patients after cardiac resuscitation may show clinical signs portending a dismal outlook. Coma alone has no predictive value in the first three days [20]. Certainly, if fixed pupils and myoclonus status epilepticus (brief, persistent, and generalized jerks in limbs and face) are associated with a sustained upward gaze, the probability of a persistent vegetative state and death is high in comatose survivors after cardiac arrest [21,22]. In 40% of comatose patients with myoclonus status epilepticus, computed tomographic scan abnormalities of multiple cerebral infarcts or cerebral edema are demonstrated. It is highly probable that status myoclonus is an agonal phenomenon and should be considered a clinical marker for devastating damage to the brain. Patients in coma after cardiac or respiratory resuscitation can be further investigated by somatosensory evoked potentials. The absence of a bilateral cortical somatosensory response (N20 and P27) with a preserved cervical somatosensory response strongly predicts a vegetative state [23]. Further management decisions should be influenced by these findings. Another population of critically ill patients with a propensity for central nervous system involvement are those who have undergone transplantation, notably liver and heart recipients. After liver transplantation, prompt awakening often signifies adequate graft function. When perioperative sedation has been excluded, failure of patients to awaken after liver transplantation may have several causes. Patients with fulminant hepatic failure are prone to the development of increased intracranial pressure from brain edema [24] and during the anhepatic phase may even have a brief surge in intracranial pressure. In an extremely unfortunate situation, brain death is diagnosed postoperatively [24]. Typically, recovery from cerebral edema takes days before level of consciousness improves. In approximately 10% of patients after liver transplantation, neurotoxicity to cyclosporine develops as early as three days after intravenous administration [25,26]. An acute confusional state with paranoid behavior, tremors, and speech abnormalities may be seen. Some patients become mute, but coma with abnormal motor responses is rare, occurring only if cyclosporine neurotoxicity is not recognized. Magnetic resonance imaging changes in the white matter have been reported with severe manifestations of cyclosporine toxicity [25]. Seizures may occur in the first postoperative days, and, if nonconvulsive status epilepticus follows, it may be a potential cause of failure to awaken. This phenomenon can be recognized in many patients by waxing and waning alertness, stereotypical behavior, and occasional twitching in the face and limbs. Central pontine myelinolysis is a less common cause for failure to awaken in recipients of liver transplants, but it may be underreported [27]. In our series of patients undergoing liver transplantation, we found an incidence of 1% and all presented with stupor. Rapid shifts in plasma osmolality and plasma sodium have been implicated [28,29], but the relationship was not evident in our survey of patients with central pontine myelinolysis [30]. Central pontine myelinolysis can be confirmed by magnetic resonance imaging, which shows a typical bat- or trident-shaped abnormality on axial T2-weighted images. (The trident shape is explained by relative preservation of the corticospinal tracts Figure 2.) Central pontine myelinolysis, although dramatic in its clinical and neuroimaging presentation, has a reasonable potential for recovery [31,32].Figure 2: Axial T2-weighted magnetic resonance image of the pons showing typical trident-shaped high-intensity signal after liver transplantation.Intracranial hematomas are uncommon (less than 1%) but have been found more often in patients with associated thrombocytopenia, bacteremia, or fungemia [33]. In some patients, a mycotic aneurysm can be implicated. Generally, infectious causes of coma after liver transplantation are uncommon. Patients with a transplanted heart generally do well in the perioperative phase. Neurotoxicity from immunosuppression (cyclosporine, OKT3) is uncommon in the intensive care unit [34-36]. Possible reasons are meticulous monitoring of OKT3 dosage by determination of the degree of decrease in CD3 cells in OKT3 and use of cyclosporine at a later stage rather than induction therapy in many immunosuppressive protocols. Patients with cardiac transplants, however, are at particular risk for ischemic stroke [36]. A history of stroke and preoperative carotid stenosis of more than 50% significantly increase the risk of ischemic stroke. After heart or heart-lung transplantation, however, ischemic stroke is most frequently associated with retained thrombi within the graft anastomosis. In summary, multiple causes of coma can be considered in critically ill patients. The setting (medical or surgical intensive care unit) may be important in the differential diagnosis. Unexplained coma should be evaluated by cerebrospinal fluid examination and repeat computed tomography scanning, but the decision to perform additional diagnostic tests in patients who are critically ill and become comatose depends on the underlying condition. In many patients, the cause of coma is obvious after careful review of the medical record. Particular attention should be paid to acute changes in laboratory values (e.g., major shifts in plasma sodium or osmolality), hypoxemic periods or cardiac arrhythmias documented during recent invasive procedures, and any recent change in medication or dosage. Computed tomography scanning should be repeated when initial findings are normal and the neurologic examination is not localizing. Cerebral infarcts may become more evident two to three days after sudden neurologic deterioration. The major causes of coma in medical and surgical intensive care units are summarized in Table 1. Generalized Muscle Weakness Fatigue can be expected in critically ill patients after they have survived their illness. An underlying neurologic abnormality should be considered when the patient is mobilized in a chair but appears considerably weak, when the patient cannot support weight, or when weaning failure cannot be readily explained by previous lung disease or new lung injury. At least three major categories have been recognized: axonal polyneuropathy (critical illness polyneuropathy), typically associated with sepsis; acute steroid myopathy, potentially associated with use of neuromuscular junction blockers; and an as yet undefined prolonged muscle weakness after neuromuscular junction blockers, which may represent a toxic myopathy. (The results of electromyographic and nerve conduction studies are often normal.) The definition of all these syndromes continues to be confusing. Many other possibilities should be considered, and in some patients a previously undiagnosed neurologic disorder may have been present that initially appeared with respiratory failure. The differential diagnoses to be considered in patients in medical and surgical intensive care units are listed in Table 2.Table 2: Causes of Generalized WeaknessaProspective studies of causes of weakness in the intensive care unit are few. Polyneuropathy is most commonly a cause of generalized weakness in the intensive care unit ("critical illness polyneuropathy") [37]. The prevalence in intensive care units is not exactly known, but it may occur in 5%-20% of all patients with sepsis and in 50% of patients remaining in the unit more than two weeks [38-40]. Polyneuropathy of critical illness is often seen in association with sepsis. Factors associated with this type of polyneuropathy include age, extended stay in the intensive care unit, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperglycemia. The clinical features of critical illness polyneuropathy are normal cranial nerve findings, although grimacing may be weak [37,38]. Limb weakness is usually severe and more prominent in the distal distribution. Areflexia is invariably present. Prominent muscle wasting may be observed. Pinprick is usually diminished in a stocking-glove pattern. The disorder resolves in a stereotypical manner: improvement in the upper and proximal portions of the lower limbs is followed by successful weaning and later recovery of the distal muscles of the lower limbs. Outcome is generally good if the patient survives the critical illness [37]. As expected with axonal regeneration, three to four months is needed for improvement. A recent study found a severe residual functional handicap in 20% of seven-year survivors with polyneuropathy [39]. Some patients have persistent weakness of the foot flexors from entrapment neuropathy of the peroneal nerve [37]. Compression neuropathy of the peroneal nerve may occur when paralyzed limbs are everted. Trochanter rolls can prevent this unnecessary complication. Electrophysiologic studies in critical illness polyneuropathy may show typical features of axonal damage, with low amplitudes of compound muscle and sensory nerve action potentials, widespread fibrillation potentials, and positive sharp waves, but nerve conduction velocities are perserved [41]. Phrenic nerve conduction is often absent [37,38]. Autopsy or sural nerve biopsy specimens show severe axonal degeneration of peripheral nerves, mostly in the distal segments. Another important cause of generalized muscle weakness is the use of neuromuscular blocking drugs, particularly pancuronium and vecuronium. Most patients recover within days after administration is discontinued, but some remain weak for weeks. The mechanism of weakness is unresolved. Careful, repeated studies of the neuromuscular junction have not been done, and findings may be normal despite marked limb weakness. A recent prospective study found that metabolites of vecuronium may accumulate in patients with renal failure, metabolic acidosis, and hypermagnesemia [42]. Electrophysiologic data for these patients with prolonged weakness were not available. Complete recovery can be expected [42]. The prevalence of prolonged weakness is low; a recent report noted the occurrence in only 1 of 58 prospectively studied patients. It is unclear whether monitoring with a peripheral nerve stimulator can prevent this complication [43]. A well-recognized but uncommon complication of intravenously administered neuromuscular blocking drugs is acute necrotic myopathy, possibly when the drug is given in combination with large doses of corticosteroids (usually up to 1 g/d) [44,45]. The typical patient in whom the complication occurs has status asthmaticus. Significant loss of myosin has been reported [45]. The outcome appears to be excellent, but data are limited. Recently, a myopathy was described in lung transplant patients. Muscle biopsy revealed loss of myosin. All patients received large doses of corticosteroids but no neuromuscular blocking agents, and sepsis did not develop. Normal creatine kinase levels virtually excluded rhabdomyolysis as a possibility. The underlying cause of this selective loss of myosin is unclear, nor is it clear whether this represents a new syndrome or a variant of acute steroid myopathy [46]. We found that severe necrotic myopathy was more common than polyneuropathy in liver transplant patients but were unable to further delineate the abnormality [47]. Rhabdomyolysis may be a source of weakness in critically ill patients. The most common causes are trauma, ischemia of large muscle compartments from arterial occlusion, and sepsis. Myoglobinuria can be found when rhabdomyolysis is massive. Many patients have considerable weakness and pain. Biceps, quadriceps, and gastrocnemius muscles are tender on palpation and may appear swollen Figure 3.Figure 3: Loss of muscle fibers from necrotic myopathy attributed to weakness caused by rhabdomyolysis.Seizures One may suspect that the circumstances surrounding critical illness make patients considerably more vulnerable to seizures, but generalized tonic-clonic seizures are uncommon in the intensive care unit. Myoclonic jerks may be more common because of their association with many of the drugs, such as ketamine and lidocaine, administered in the medical intensive care unit. Acute metabolic alterations, unpredictable pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics, and multiple drug regimens are precipitating factors. Two studies assessing seizures in the intensive care unit have been published [1,48]. In a two-year prospective study of neurologic complications in 1758 patients, 34 had simple partial seizures, 6 had complex partial seizures, and 20 had seizures that were generalized at onset. Status epilepticus eventually developed in six patients [1]. Most of these patients had a stroke or an infectious disease at the time of seizure. In a recent study from the Mayo Clinic covering nine years, 213 of 27,723 patients (0.8%) admitted to intensive care units had at least one episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizure during their stay in a unit [48]. Of the 213 patients, 103 had a history of seizures, 20 had abused alcohol or drugs, 8 were recovering from organ transplantation, and 27 had surgical trauma or head injury. In the remaining 55 patients, seizures were new in onset. Drug-associated seizures in the intensive care unit are often the result of toxicity [2]. Some antibiotics particularly lower the threshold for seizures, but renal failure or a recent sudden increase in antibiotic dosage is a more common precipitating event. For example, imipenem, but particularly increased levels of cilastatin, rather than the active antibiotic, is a well-known cause of seizures. Drugs associated with seizures in intensive care units are summarized in Table 3.Table 3: Drugs Associated with Seizures in the Intensive Care UnitSeizures associated with drug withdrawal may occur in one third of the patients. In a recent study that specifically addressed new-onset seizures, 18 of 55 patients had seizures associated with drug withdrawal (mostly narcotic analgesics) [48]. Drug toxicity was comparatively uncommon, observed in eight patients (from documented antibiotic toxicity in five and from antiarrhythmic drugs in three). In many narcotics were administered for pain management, and in all patients, moderate doses were repeated intramuscularly for at least one week. Seizures occurred two to four days after sudden withdrawal of narcotics. In patients who have alcohol-related seizures, most of which occur in those with a history of heavy drinking, diagnosis is difficult [49]. Very frequently, a single seizure, almost always self-limiting, develops in these patients, but delirium tremens may follow [49]. An underlying structural lesion needs to be excluded by cranial computed tomographic scan [50]. Benzodiazepines are frequently used to maintain sedation in mechanically ventilated patients. Nonconvulsive status epilepticus may occur after discontinuation of long-term administration of benzodiazepines [51]. Metabolic disorders increase the risk of seizures, but risk is related to the severity of the derangement [52-55]. The risk of seizures developing due to electrolyte abnormalities is low. Most seizures in the intensive care unit occur in patients with postoperative hyponatremia, and the cause is often iatrogenic. Most patients with severe hyponatremia already have an impaired level of consciousness, which is soon followed by generalized tonic-clonic seizures. A very unusual syndrome associated with postoperative hyponatremia in young, healthy women has been described [52]. Arieff [52] and others are credited for their description of very severe hyponatremia in healthy women after elective surgery, but this complication was not found in a recent survey at the Mayo Clinic [55]. Many of these women had excessive administration of free water, resulting in sodium levels of less than 110 mEq/L. Vomiting, most likely associated with narcotics or postoperative syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone, may also have contributed. All patients had grand mal seizures followed within one hour by respiratory arrest. Many remained in a vegetative state, and several patients became brain dead. More hospital surveys are necessary to delineate the prevalence of this catastrophic syndrome. Postoperative severe hyponatremia occurs in men undergoing transurethral resection of the prostate, but the outcome is good despite seizures [56]. In this category of patients, serum osmolarity is high from bladder absorption of hypertonic glycine, which is frequently used as an irrigant. Rapid excretion of glycine by the kidney restores plasma osmolarity. This result suggests that the changes in osmolarity are much more important than a change in plasma sodium and that differences should not be attributed to sex. Hypoglycemia may cause tonic-clonic seizures, but in one of the largest series of patients with symptomatic hypoglycemia, many were known to have epilepsy or were alcoholics [54]. Focal seizures may occur and do not necessarily implicate a preexisting structural lesion. Seizures are more prevalent in critically ill patients with hyperglycemia [53]. Nonketotic hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia may eventually result in refractory status epilepticus, usually with poor outcome. Tonic-clonic seizures may occur when the ionized serum calcium concentration is less than 3 mEq/L. Hypocalcemia in a critically ill patient is usually associated with radical neck dissection surgery but may also result from parathyroid suppression by sepsis, pancreatitis, aminoglycosides, or changes in serum magnesium [57]. Much more commonly, hypocalcemic patients have muscle cramps and irregular twitching, which should not be interpreted as focal seizures. Seizures in patients with transplanted organs often indicate that the immunosuppressive drug has reached toxic levels [58]. In patients with transplanted livers, the incidence of seizures is increased by cyclosporine, OKT3, or FK 506 toxicity Figure 4, ischemic anoxic encephalopathy, subdural hematoma, or fungal abscess [59,60].Figure 4: Upper left panel, Magnetic resonance imaging findings in a patient with seizures and FK 506 toxicity. Note marked hyperintensity signal in the globus pallidus on T1-weighted images, typically seen in patients with advanced liver disease. Upper right panel, Marked hyperintensity signal in white matter and cortex in occipital lobe appears on T2-weighted images in a patient with seizures and an impaired level of consciousness. Lower panels, There was complete resolution of both abnormalities in one month.Conclusion The management plan is often reassessed when additional neurologic injury develops in patients in intensive care units. In some patients with a severe underlying illness, an acute neurologic event is a final complication; in others, it is a temporary setback. The outcome from neurologic complications can be quite favorable, but signs of poor prognosis should be identified early and taken into account when management decisions are made. The clinical spectrum of the neurologic aspects of critical illness is beginning to emerge and become defined.

papers.title: Chronic sleep curtailment, even without extended (>16-h) wakefulness, degrades human vigilance performance
papers.abstract: Significance Millions of individuals obtain insufficient sleep on a daily basis, which leads to impaired performance. Whether these decrements are caused by short sleep duration or extended wakefulness is unknown. In this study, healthy volunteers were randomized into either a chronically sleep-restricted or control protocol while living on a 20-h “day,” thus enabling short sleep without extended wakefulness. We demonstrate that chronic insufficient sleep, even without extended wakefulness, leads to neurobehavioral performance decrements at all times of the day, even when the circadian system is promoting arousal. These findings have implications for the understanding of basic physiology, the substantial population who chronically obtains insufficient sleep, and all of us who depend on sleep-restricted individuals working in safety-sensitive occupations.
papers.venue: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

papers.title: A Syndrome Associated with Sleeping Late
papers.abstract: A syndrome sometimes associated with sleeping late is identified in a student population. It is recognized as feelings of being worn-out, tired, lethargic, and irritable, with fuzzy thinking and difficulty in getting going. When it occurs, it tends to last for an average of 4.4 hr. This syndrome is particularly marked following sleep of 10 or more hr when the individual is not making up a sleep deficit. Under these conditions, the worn-out syndrome is more typical than feeling just great. These data suggest the testable hypothesis that optimal durations of sleep fall into a relatively narrow band and that disruptive psycho-physiological effects are sustained with both too much and too little sleep.

papers.title: 抑郁障碍的社会经济负担及对策
papers.abstract: 抑郁障碍(depressive disorder)是人群中最常见的精神障碍之一,属于心境障碍(mood disorder)的一种,以情感低落或兴趣减退为主要特征,通常伴有相应的认知、行为、心理生物学、躯体症状以及人际关系方面的改变或紊乱[1].抑郁障碍普遍发生于全球各个国家、社会各个阶层和各种文化背景的人群中,已经成为影响和危害人类健康的公共卫生问题之一。

papers.title: Determinants and Measurements of Daytime Sleepiness
papers.abstract: Daytime sleepiness is the primary complaint of patients who present to sleep clinics. Although the actual prevalence of clinically relevant sleepiness in America is unknown, it has been estimated that significant sleep loss exists in up to one-third or more of normal adults (1,2). Sleepiness has an important impact on general health and functional status, influencing how individuals perceive their energy and fatigue levels (3). Sleep deprivation and sleepiness in general have been associated with poor job performance, anxiety, difficulties in personal relations, and an increased risk for fatal and nonfatal automobile accidents, daytime sleepiness resulting from chronic partial or total sleep deprivation has been demonstrated to result in neurocognitive deficits and alterations in mood, and more recently to cause alterations in physiological and endocrine functions (4–26). Sleep deprivation has also been directly or indirectly linked to several recent catastrophes including the Exxon Valdez oil spill, space shuttle Challenger explosion, and the Three Mile Island near-meltdown.

papers.title: Circadian Disorders, Insomnia, and Parasomniasa
papers.abstract: Abstract This chapter reviews circadian disorders, insomnias, and parasomnias. These are common sleep disorders encountered in clinical practice. Each requires a careful review of potential contributing factors and a multifaceted approach to treatment. Circadian rhythm disorders have a misalignment between a desired sleep schedule and the circadian sleep-wake rhythm. Insomnia is one of the most common medical complaints and increases in prevalence with age. Parasomnias are abnormal states of behavior and experience in which basic instincts are inappropriately unleashed during sleep; these experiential or physical phenomena are often undesirable and nondeliberate.

papers.title: HYSTERIC LETHARGY WITH REPORT OF CASES.
papers.abstract: A deep interest, both lay and professional, has always been manifested in the various states of morbid unconsciousness, especially when not associated with other obvious disturbances of health. To an involuntary, profound, unaccountable and especially more or less prolonged state of apparent sleep has always been assigned a certain element of mystery. While the mystery, at least in the transcendental sense, has largely faded, the interest and obscurity remain and there is recognized at present a group of cases with every gradation of intensity between moderately excessive somnolence and a stupor from which no amount of stimulation will arouse the patient; and varying in duration from a few minutes to several months. It is understood that the coma of gross brain disease, drug narcosis, etc., is excluded. A considerable number of these cases have been of toxemic origin.
